Author: simonvic
Content:
hey guys, I've made my own weight calculation system for items in order to fix this issue https://feedback.bistudio.com/T164081 , and I'm now looking into possible performance improvements.
Right now the weight is computed both server and client side, and I was wondering if, performance wise, would be better to just compute it on the server and then syncronize it with `RegisterNetSyncVariableInt()` to the clients.

Author: simonvic
Content: Considering that I have to do this for every `EntityAI`, what would be better?

Author: simonvic
Content: How much is the performance hit of net sync variables, and most importantly how safe and reliable are they?

Author: affenb3rt
Content: They are pretty reliable and safe to use. Overhead I think it's just more data that needs to be synced. If it's added to each item that stacks up a lot I would say so it should increase traffic quite a bit

Author: affenb3rt
Content: How often do you recalculate the weight? I think that's more where the performance gain or loss will be overall

Author: affenb3rt
Content: On a complete sidenote: where does the client actively involve the weight in it's calculations?

Author: simonvic
Content:
I keep the weight in memory and update it when needed:
I'll simplify because there are some edge cases that I had to tackle; considering any `EntityAI` like a n-ary tree, I update its weight when another `EntityAI` gets into/out its inventory (cargo or attachment) and then recursively update the parents (idk how much the depth of the tree could be, so in the future I might use an iterative approach).
I also update the weight when the `quantity` of an item changes (e.g. eating an apple, boling water etc.)

Content: Attempting an answer to my own question in case anyone ever searches.  The config.cpp defines the root of the pbo.  So if a config.cpp is contained within a folder named "Mymod" it will produce a pbo with the name Mymod.pbo that contains the contents of that folder along with all of its subfolders. I copied the exact same  config.cpp that I had in my earplugs\scripts folder  into the earplugs\data folder, which resulted in a new pbo called data.pbo in addition to the scripts.pbo that was produced earlier. This two pbo method also solves the original `cannot open layout` error, although I've been told that the better practice is to keep the data folder together with the asset that depends on it. Wiki sources collected here for convenience. <https://community.bistudio.com/wiki/DayZ:Modding_Basics#Creating_a_mod>, <https://dayzmodding.dev/en/Tutorials/config-explained>.
